evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew is resistant to defeaters as alternative explanations do not sufficiently account for the observed coordination failures in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t2_interim context.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features of human factors and crew resource management failures identified in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t2_interim case.

slot_statements.availability: The environmental or marking deficiency must be present and identifiable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA aircraft during the hist_t2_interim period on 12-25.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The identification of the environmental or marking deficiency should be robust against potential defeaters or exceptions within the context of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA hist_t2_interim period on 12-25.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The environmental or marking deficiency should align with the key features and characteristics relevant to the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA model and the hist_t2_interim timeframe.

slot_statements.availability: Mechanical/control failure occurred in the Boeing 737-8AS with tail number 9H-QAA on 12-25 during the hist_t2_interim period.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The mechanical/control failure in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25 during hist_t2_interim is resistant to common defeaters based on available evidence.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The mechanical/control failure aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident dated 12-25 within the hist_t2_interim scope.

slot_statements.availability: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is documented and observable within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the 12-25 hist_t2_interim timeframe.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The procedural deviation in pushback execution withstands potential counterarguments and alternative explanations within the context of Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t2_interim data.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with key features identified for Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA operations during the 12-25 hist_t2_interim period.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was evident and documented during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25 in the hist_t2_interim scope.

defeaters: If evidence showed effective communication and coordination preventing the incident
If the communication breakdown was not documented or was contradicted by other reports

quotes.exact_quote: The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.
He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence directly documents communication and coordination actions and failures among the crew during the incident, including the trainee driver asking the instructor to take over (H2), the instructor advising the trainee (H3), and the lack of warning signals from other crew members about the impending collision (H8).
outcome.uncertainty_source: limited detail on the full communication exchanges and coordination protocols

node.statement: Mechanical/control failure occurred in the Boeing 737-8AS with tail number 9H-QAA on 12-25 during the hist_t2_interim period.

defeaters: Evidence of mechanical or control system malfunction or failure in the aircraft during the incident.
outcome.reasoning_summary: No evidence indicates any mechanical or control failure of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25 during the hist_t2_interim period; all evidence describes tug driver actions and aircraft movement without mention of mechanical/control failure (H1-H9).

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features of human factors and crew resource management failures identified in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t2_interim case.

assumptions: Visual signals and informal communication are key components of crew resource management in this context
Lack of warning from wingman and headset operator indicates coordination breakdown
Trainee status implies potential for human factors related errors
defeaters: If evidence showed effective communication and coordination preventing errors
If the crew had clear, reliable communication protocols that were followed
If the collision was caused by external factors unrelated to crew communication

quotes.exact_quote: The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence shows communication methods (visual signals) were insufficient and that key personnel (wingman, headset operator) did not warn of impending collision (H8). The trainee driver was qualified but inexperienced (H9), and the instructor was advising during pushback (H3), indicating coordination challenges consistent with human factors and CRM failures.
outcome.uncertainty_source: lack of explicit analysis linking observed communication issues directly to CRM failure frameworks

node.statement: The environmental or marking deficiency must be present and identifiable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA aircraft during the hist_t2_interim period on 12-25.

defeaters: Evidence showing a missing, unclear, or inadequate environmental or marking feature on the aircraft or at the TRP during the specified period.
outcome.reasoning_summary: No evidence indicates the presence or identification of an environmental or marking deficiency on the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t2_interim period on 12-25; the TRP markings and clearance are described as existing and known (H7, H9), and no deficiency is reported.

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is documented and observable within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the 12-25 hist_t2_interim timeframe.

defeaters: If evidence showed the pushback was executed strictly according to procedure without deviation
If the incident occurred outside the specified timeframe or aircraft
If the deviation was not documented or observable

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.
After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence directly documents the procedural deviation during pushback execution on the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA in the specified timeframe, including the continuation beyond the TRP and collision with the blast barrier (H4), the tug instructor taking over (H2, H3), and the lack of adequate warning signals (H8).
outcome.uncertainty_source: None significant; the history provides detailed direct observations

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with key features identified for Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA operations during the 12-25 hist_t2_interim period.

defeaters: Direct documentation or analysis explicitly linking the procedural deviation to key features for Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the 12-25 hist_t2_interim period
Evidence showing that the deviation was inconsistent with known key features

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence shows a procedural deviation occurred (H4) and describes the TRP and clearance (H7), as well as the signaling method and its limitations (H8). The trainee's awareness of TRP is noted (H9). However, no explicit reference confirms that the deviation aligns with key features identified for Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA operations during the specified period, so alignment is uncertain.

node.statement: The mechanical/control failure aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident dated 12-25 within the hist_t2_interim scope.

defeaters: Evidence of mechanical or control system malfunction in the aircraft or tug during the incident
Reports or data indicating failure of mechanical components or control systems
outcome.reasoning_summary: No evidence in the provided history items indicates any mechanical or control failure; the incident appears related to procedural or human factors during pushback.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew is resistant to defeaters as alternative explanations do not sufficiently account for the observed coordination failures in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t2_interim context.

assumptions: Communication/coordination breakdown refers to failure among crew and ground personnel involved in pushback
Alternative explanations would include equipment failure or environmental factors not documented here
defeaters: If evidence showed effective communication and warnings were given but ignored
If alternative explanations such as equipment failure or environmental factors were documented and sufficient
If the crew had clear situational awareness and still the incident occurred

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Direct evidence (H1, H3, H4, H8) shows communication channels existed but failed to prevent the pushback beyond the TRP and collision, indicating coordination breakdown. The lack of warnings from wingman or headset operator despite proximity supports resistance to alternative explanations.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No detailed information on alternative explanations or equipment status; limited insight into internal crew communication beyond headset operator

node.statement: The mechanical/control failure in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25 during hist_t2_interim is resistant to common defeaters based on available evidence.

assumptions: Mechanical/control failure would manifest as inability to stop or control the tug/aircraft movement
Human factors and communication issues are considered defeaters to mechanical/control failure claims
defeaters: If evidence showed the mechanical/control failure was confirmed by technical diagnostics and not due to human error or communication issues
If there were clear indications that the failure persisted despite all known defeaters being addressed

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence shows the aircraft moved beyond the TRP and hit a barrier despite signals intended to stop the tug (H4, H8). The tug instructor noted the visual stop signal was insufficient and no warnings were received, indicating possible human or procedural failures rather than a mechanical/control failure resistant to defeaters.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct technical evidence on mechanical/control failure or its resistance to defeaters; only operational history and human factors are described.

node.statement: The environmental or marking deficiency should align with the key features and characteristics relevant to the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA model and the hist_t2_interim timeframe.

assumptions: The TRP markings and blast barrier placement are considered part of the environmental and marking features relevant to the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA model and timeframe.
The trainee driver's awareness of the TRP implies the markings should have been effective.
defeaters: If there were evidence that the TRP markings were compliant with all relevant standards and clearly visible to all personnel involved, or if the trainee driver was not aware of the TRP, this would change the assessment.
If the blast barrier placement was standard and accounted for in operational procedures, the deficiency might be less relevant.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view.
Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence directly references the TRP ground markings and their relation to the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA model, including the clearance and the incident of the aircraft moving beyond the TRP and hitting the blast barrier (H4, H7). The tug instructor's comments on the visual signal method and the trainee driver's awareness of the TRP support the assessment of environmental and marking deficiencies fitting the key features (H8, H9).
outcome.uncertainty_source: The exact visibility and clarity of the TRP markings and the adequacy of the visual signals are somewhat ambiguous.

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution withstands potential counterarguments and alternative explanations within the context of Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t2_interim data.

assumptions: The procedural deviation refers to the aircraft moving beyond the TRP and hitting the blast barrier
The context is limited to the described pushback event and personnel involved
defeaters: If evidence showed effective communication or intervention by wingman or headset operator preventing the deviation
If the procedural deviation was caused by external factors beyond the crew's control
If the tug instructor or trainee had prior knowledge or training that contradicted the deviation

quotes.exact_quote: The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence shows the procedural deviation (continuing beyond the TRP and hitting the blast barrier) occurred despite the trainee stopping and the instructor taking over (H2, H3, H4). The instructor noted limitations in communication signals that could have prevented timely stopping (H8). No warnings were received from other personnel, indicating the deviation was not effectively countered by alternative explanations or interventions.
outcome.uncertainty_source: lack of detailed information on communication effectiveness and possible external factors influencing the pushback

node.statement: The identification of the environmental or marking deficiency should be robust against potential defeaters or exceptions within the context of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA hist_t2_interim period on 12-25.

assumptions: The TRP marking described in H7 is the environmental or marking deficiency referenced.
The visual signaling method described in H8 is the primary method relevant to defeater resistance.
defeaters: If additional evidence showed more effective or redundant signaling methods were in place and consistently used, this would increase robustness.
If the TRP marking was ambiguous or poorly visible, that would reduce robustness.

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7 describes the TRP marking and clearance, indicating a defined environmental marking. Evidence H8 highlights limitations in the visual signaling method used to stop the tug, suggesting potential exceptions or defeaters to the robustness of the identification of the marking deficiency. Together, these imply the identification is somewhat robust but not fully resistant to defeaters.
outcome.uncertainty_source: The evidence does not explicitly evaluate all possible exceptions or alternative signaling methods; the assessment relies on limited historical statements about signaling and marking clarity.

children_spec.statement: Pushback procedure deviated from standard communication protocols
children_spec.test_procedure: Review recorded communications and compare with standard pushback communication protocols to identify deviations

children_spec.statement: Pushback vehicle operator did not follow prescribed pushback path or speed limits
children_spec.test_procedure: Analyze pushback vehicle tracking data and compare with prescribed path and speed limits

children_spec.statement: Ground crew failed to perform required safety checks before pushback
children_spec.test_procedure: Examine ground crew checklists and reports to verify completion of safety checks prior to pushback

children_spec.statement: Aircraft systems were not configured according to pushback procedural requirements
children_spec.test_procedure: Inspect aircraft system logs and configurations during pushback to confirm adherence to procedural requirements

children_spec.statement: Required environmental markings are physically present at the location
children_spec.test_procedure: Inspect the location to verify the presence of all required environmental markings

children_spec.statement: Required environmental markings are visible under current lighting and weather conditions
children_spec.test_procedure: Assess visibility of markings during the incident conditions, including lighting and weather

children_spec.statement: Required environmental markings are maintained in a legible and unambiguous state
children_spec.test_procedure: Evaluate the condition and clarity of markings to ensure they are not faded or obscured

node.statement: Aircraft systems were not configured according to pushback procedural requirements

defeaters: Direct evidence that aircraft systems were configured correctly according to pushback procedures
Evidence that the continued movement beyond TRP was due to other factors unrelated to system configuration

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 shows the aircraft moved beyond the designated TRP point, indicating a deviation from procedural requirements. H8 suggests communication and signaling methods were insufficient, implying possible system or procedural configuration issues. However, no direct statement confirms aircraft systems were not configured per pushback procedures.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit evidence confirming or denying aircraft system configuration status relative to pushback procedural requirements

node.statement: Ground crew failed to perform required safety checks before pushback

defeaters: Direct evidence of omitted safety checks by ground crew
Statements or reports indicating safety checks were performed properly
Evidence of communication or procedural compliance before pushback

quotes.exact_quote: The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

outcome.reasoning_summary: No direct evidence states that ground crew failed to perform required safety checks before pushback. The tug instructor noted limitations in visual signals and lack of warnings from wingman or headset operator (H8), and the trainee was qualified and aware of procedures (H9). This suggests procedural adherence but possible communication or situational awareness issues rather than outright failure to perform safety checks.
